'''Habari''' ({{pron-en|hÉËbÉri}}) is a [[Free software|free]] and [[Open source software|open source]] [[Weblog software|blog engine]] written in [[PHP]] and currently supports [[MySQL]], [[SQLite]] and [[PostgreSQL]] for the database backend.<ref>[http://wiki.habariproject.org/en/Installation#Before_You_Install Habari Project Wiki - Before You Install]</ref> It gets its name from the [[Swahili language|Swahili]] greeting ''habari,'' which means "(what's the) news".<ref>[http://www.kamusiproject.org/en/lookup/sw?Word=habari&utm_source=self&utm_medium=link&utm_campaign=linktoSwahili Kamusi Project - Translation of "habari"]</ref>
==Features== * Modular, object-oriented core for easy extensibility<ref>[http://asymptomatic.net/2007/01/09/29/whats-up asymptomatic.net - Release Announcement]</ref> * Supports multiple database backends<ref>[http://wiki.habariproject.org/en/Features Habari Project Wiki - Features page]</ref> * Uses prepared statements throughout to protect against [[SQL injection]] attacks * Media silos to directly access various ways of media storage, like [[Flickr]], [http://www.viddler.com Viddler], or the server's filesystem * [[Atom (standard)|Atom Publishing Protocol]] support * Multiple users (authors) supported * Multiple sites on one installation supported (such as blog1.example.com and blog2.example.com) (note, however, that Habari does not yet support multiple blogs on one domain such as <nowiki>http://example.com/blog1 and http://example.com/blog2</nowiki><ref>[http://habariproject.org/forums/comments.php?DiscussionID=19&page=1#Item_0 Comparison of Habari to WPmu])</ref> * Support for static content ("pages") * [[Plug-in (computing)|Plugin]] support * [[Tag (metadata)|Tag]] support * [[WordPress]] importer
==History== The Habari project was started in October 2006<ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/habari-dev/about Habari Project Mailing List - about page]</ref> to develop a modern blogging platform. The focus is on utilizing current technology, such as PHP 5, [[PHP Data Objects]], and [[object-oriented programming]], and the support of modern standards, such as the Atom Publishing Protocol.
The first "developer release" was released on April 3, 2007. Habari 0.2 followed on August 4, version 0.3 on November 5, version 0.4 on February 22, version 0.5 on July 27, 2008, version 0.6 on April 6, 2009, and version 0.7 on April 1, 2011. Version 0.7.1 followed on May 12, 2011.
Habari was a finalist in the 2008 SourceForge Community Choice Awards in the category of Best New Project.<ref>[http://sourceforge.net/community/cca08-finalists SourceForge Community Choice Awards - Finalist listing]</ref>

==Development model== Habari is developed by the Habari community, in a meritocratic process inspired by the [[Apache Software Foundation]].<ref>[http://www.apache.org/foundation/how-it-works.html#meritocracy How the ASF works - The Apache Software Foundation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Permission to commit code is handled liberally, with new contributors easily getting access to their own branches in the main source code repository. The decision-making process always involves the community, and in most cases decisions are made by community consensus. Some decisions, such as the decision that a new version should be released, are finalized by a vote amongst the Habari committers.<ref>[http://wiki.habariproject.org/en/Cabal Habari Project Wiki - Cabal page]</ref> This ensures that different opinions are heard and discussion is not stifled.
